speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: SCENE IV. London. The palace.

speaker: WARWICK
text_entry: Enter QUEEN ELIZABETH and RIVERS

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Madam, what makes you in this sudden change?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Why brother Rivers, are you yet to learn

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: What late misfortune is befall'n King Edward?

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: What! loss of some pitch'd battle against Warwick?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: No, but the loss of his own royal person.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Then is my sovereign slain?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Ay, almost slain, for he is taken prisoner,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Either betray'd by falsehood of his guard

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Or by his foe surprised at unawares:

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: And, as I further have to understand,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Is new committed to the Bishop of York,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Fell Warwick's brother and by that our foe.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: These news I must confess are full of grief;

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Yet, gracious madam, bear it as you may:

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: Warwick may lose, that now hath won the day.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Till then fair hope must hinder life's decay.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: And I the rather wean me from despair

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: For love of Edward's offspring in my womb:

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: This is it that makes me bridle passion

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: And bear with mildness my misfortune's cross;

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Ay, ay, for this I draw in many a tear

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: And stop the rising of blood-sucking sighs,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Lest with my sighs or tears I blast or drown

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: King Edward's fruit, true heir to the English crown.

speaker: RIVERS
text_entry: But, madam, where is Warwick then become?

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: I am inform'd that he comes towards London,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: To set the crown once more on Henry's head:

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Guess thou the rest; King Edward's friends must down,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: But, to prevent the tyrant's violence,--

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: For trust not him that hath once broken faith,--

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: I'll hence forthwith unto the sanctuary,

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: To save at least the heir of Edward's right:

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: There shall I rest secure from force and fraud.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Come, therefore, let us fly while we may fly:

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: If Warwick take us we are sure to die.

speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
text_entry: Exeunt
